JOURNALIST:

Mr Reithâs announcement yesterday that he is going to support the ânoâ case becauseâ¦[inaudible] â¦a popularly elected President. Do you think that it is dangerous thinking or supporting the idea of a popularly elected President?

PRIME MINISTER:

Well, you should go and talk to Mr Reith about that. Look, I made a promise to the Australian people before the last election that there would be a referendum on this issue. I have always made it plain myself that I am against change. We are an open, free, democratic party and everybody has got a view and the Australian people will decide the issue.

JOURNALIST:

Do you still have reservations though about a popularly elected President?

PRIME MINISTER:

Look, I am not going to get into a running commentary. My position is clear. I am against change and I certainly have expressed views about a popularly elected presidency in the past. But, look, if you want to ask questions on behalf of Mr Turnbull go to some other forum.

JOURNALIST:

My views have not altered.

And we are putting a question to them that faithfully and truthfully reflects the proposition. The proposition that has been put to the Australian people is that this country should become a republic with a President chosen by two-thirds of the members of the House of Representatives on the nomination of the Prime Minister and with the support of the Leader of the Opposition. Now, thatâs what the convention voted for, thatâs Mr Turnbullâs model, thatâs what we are putting. I donât know what the man is complaining about.

â¦alcohol has officially replaced speed as the worst killer on [inaudible]â¦
